sn10.5:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn10.5:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn10.5:1.1.comm: The commentary explains that Sānu was a disillusioned novice who had returned home planning to disrobe. | Sānu was perhaps named after the planet Saturn (Sanskrit śani; cf. SN 10.7). The Sanskrit word for planet (graha, cf. Pali gayha at DN 20:17.3) shows their role as “seizers”. The later Suśrutasaṁhitā-uttaratantra details the entities that cause such seizures in children (60), corresponding to the nine planets (27). Seizures or fits were treated as medical, spiritual, and astrological in cause and remedy.

sn10.5:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarissā upāsikāya sānu nāma putto yakkhena gahito hoti.
sn10.5:1.2.eng: Now at that time a certain lay woman had a son named Sānu who had been seized by a native spirit.
sn10.5:1.2.comm: Elsewhere we find possession by Māra expressed as anvāviṭṭha, literally “inhabited”, where the victims are made to behave badly but are otherwise normal (SN 4.18:1.4, MN 50:14.2; cf. Sanskrit āviṣṭa). Gahita here is also used for Rāhu “seizing” the Sun and Moon (SN 2.10:1.2). The commentary says he was shaking on the ground, eyes rolling and mouth foaming, i.e. having a “seizure”. This was not ill-motivated, for the yakkha was trying to prevent him from disrobing. Compare those who, though “seized by a gandharva” (gandharvagṛhīta), remain perfectly cogent (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.3.1, 3.7.1).

sn10.5:1.3.pli: Atha kho sā upāsikā paridevamānā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn10.5:1.3.eng: And as that lay woman wept, on that occasion she recited these verses:
sn10.5:1.3.comm: PTS editions insert an extra verse below, but it seems to be a scribal error.

sn10.5:2.1.eng: “I have heard this from the perfected ones.
sn10.5:2.1.comm: See AN 3.70 for a detailed description of the eight-factored sabbath.

sn10.5:2.2.eng: The native spirits will not mess with anyone

sn10.5:3.2.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

sn10.5:3.3.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

sn10.5:3.4.eng: as well as on the fortnight of special displays.

sn10.5:4.1.eng: “What you heard from the perfected ones is right.

sn10.5:4.2.eng: The native spirits will not mess with anyone

sn10.5:5.2.eng: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,

sn10.5:5.3.eng: and the eighth day of the fortnight,

sn10.5:5.4.eng: as well as on the fortnight of special displays.

sn10.5:6.1.eng: When Sānu regains consciousness tell him

sn10.5:6.2.eng: this saying of the native spirits:
sn10.5:6.2.comm: It’s interesting that the Buddha cites a yakkha saying to someone recovering from a yakkha-induced seizure. At Thig 12.1:12.1 these lines are attributed to the nun Puṇṇikā.

sn10.5:7.1.eng: If you should do a bad deed,

sn10.5:7.3.eng: you won’t be freed from suffering,

sn10.5:7.4.eng: though you fly away and flee.”

sn10.5:8.1.comm: Sānu has recovered from his seizure to see his weeping mother. This verse appears without any context at Thag 1.44.

sn10.5:8.2.eng: or for one who’s alive but missing.

sn10.5:8.3.eng: I’m alive and you can see me,

sn10.5:8.4.eng: so mum, why do you weep for me?”

sn10.5:9.1.comm: Here’s the plot twist: the mother’s real worry is not the seizure, but that her son will fall prey to desire and suffering. See SN 20.10:3.5, “For it is death in the training of the Noble One to reject the training and return to a lesser life.”

sn10.5:9.2.eng: or for one who’s alive but missing.

sn10.5:9.3.eng: But someone who has given up sensual pleasures

sn10.5:9.4.eng: only to come back here again:

sn10.5:9.5.eng: they cry for them as well,

sn10.5:9.6.eng: for though still alive they’re really dead.

sn10.5:10.1.eng: My dear, you’ve been rescued from hot coals,

sn10.5:10.2.eng: and you want to plunge right back in them!

sn10.5:10.3.eng: My dear, you’ve been rescued from the abyss,
sn10.5:10.3.comm: This is, I think, the only case in the EBTs where “inferno” might be suggested for naraka. Elsewhere in early Pali, however, it means “cliff, abyss” (MN 49:5.9, mn86:6.15](), Snp 3.11:28.4, Thag 16.8:4.2).

sn10.5:10.4.eng: and you want to plunge right back there!

sn10.5:11.1.eng: Hurry up, good luck to you!
sn10.5:11.1.comm: Here we see the origin of the term of address bhante, i.e. “good luck to thee”.

sn10.5:11.3.eng: A valuable saved from a fire,

sn10.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn10.6:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn10.6:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā anuruddho rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya dhammapadāni bhāsati.
sn10.6:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Anuruddha rose at the crack of dawn and recited passages of the teaching.
sn10.6:1.2.comm: “Passages of the teaching” is dhammapadāni.

sn10.6:1.3.pli: Atha kho piyaṅkaramātā yakkhinī puttakaṃ evaṃ tosesi:
sn10.6:1.3.eng: Then the native spirit Piyaṅkara’s Mother soothed her little child, saying:
sn10.6:1.3.comm: Piyaṅkara means “endearing”. Here we see clearly the role of the yakkha as deity of childhood.

sn10.6:2.2.eng: A mendicant recites passages of the teaching.

sn10.6:2.4.eng: we can practice for our welfare.

sn10.6:3.1.eng: Let us restrain ourselves from harming living creatures,

sn10.6:3.3.eng: We should train ourselves well in ethics,

sn10.6:3.4.eng: and hopefully we’ll be freed from the goblin realm.”

sn10.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn10.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn10.7:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhū nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn10.7:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

sn10.7:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn10.7:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn10.7:1.4.pli: Atha kho punabbasumātā yakkhinī puttake evaṃ tosesi:
sn10.7:1.4.eng: Then the native spirit Punabbasu’s Mother soothed her little children, saying:
sn10.7:1.4.comm: This is another ode to the maternal love of the female yakkha.

sn10.7:2.2.comm: Punabbasu is a lunar mansion or asterism, roughly equivalent to Gemini. The child is probably named after the asterism, which suggests Uttarā was too; there are three asterisms with Uttara in their names (cf. DN 14:1.12.15).

sn10.7:2.3.eng: For I want to listen to the teaching

sn10.7:2.4.eng: of the Teacher, the supreme Buddha.

sn10.7:3.2.eng: is the release from all ties.

sn10.7:4.1.eng: In this world, your own child is dear;

sn10.7:4.2.eng: in this world, your own husband is dear;

sn10.7:4.3.eng: but even greater than that is my love

sn10.7:5.2.eng: dear as they are, can free you from suffering;

sn10.7:5.3.eng: as listening to the true teaching

sn10.7:6.1.eng: In this world mired in suffering,

sn10.7:6.2.eng: fettered by old age and death,

sn10.7:6.3.eng: I want to listen to the teaching

sn10.7:6.5.eng: which frees you from old age and death.

sn10.7:7.4.eng: for it’s nice to listen to the true teaching.

sn10.7:7.5.eng: And it’s because we haven’t understood the teaching

sn10.7:7.6.eng: that we live in suffering, Mom.

sn10.7:8.1.eng: He is a beacon for those who are lost

sn10.7:8.3.eng: The Buddha, bearing his final body,

sn10.7:9.1.eng: “It’s good that my child’s so astute,

sn10.7:9.2.eng: this child I bore and suckled!

sn10.7:9.3.eng: My child loves the pure teaching

sn10.7:10.4.eng: I have seen the noble truths!”

sn10.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati sītavane.
sn10.8:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Grove.
sn10.8:1.1.comm: This story, which tells of the conversion of the Buddha’s chief layman follower, is detailed further in the Vinaya at Kd 16:4.1.1. | The Cool Grove was a pleasant place to meditate, notable as the place where the Buddha moderated the monk Soṇa’s excessive striving (AN 6.55).

sn10.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati rājagahaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
sn10.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had arrived at Rājagaha on some business.
sn10.8:1.2.comm: His given name was Sudatta, but he is usually known by the sobriquet Anāthapiṇḍika, “feeder of the poor”. He features in countless discourses as the ideal of the generous lay follower.

sn10.8:1.4.eng: a rumor that a Buddha had arisen in the world.

sn10.8:1.5.pli: Tāvadeva ca pana bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo hoti. Athassa anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa etadahosi:
sn10.8:1.5.eng: Right away he wanted to go and see the Buddha, but he thought,

sn10.8:1.6.eng: “It’s too late to go and see the Buddha today.

sn10.8:1.7.pli: Sve dānāhaṃ kālena bhagavantaṃ dassanāya gamissāmī”ti buddhagatāya satiyā nipajji.
sn10.8:1.7.eng: I’ll go and see him tomorrow.” He went to bed thinking of the Buddha.

sn10.8:1.8.pli: Rattiyā sudaṃ tikkhattuṃ vuṭṭhāsi pabhātanti maññamāno.
sn10.8:1.8.eng: During the night he got up three times thinking it was morning.

sn10.8:1.9.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sivathikadvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
sn10.8:1.9.eng: Then he approached the Sivaka Gate,

sn10.8:1.10.eng: and non-human beings opened it for him.

sn10.8:1.11.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nagaramhā nikkhamantassa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
sn10.8:1.11.eng: But as he was leaving the city, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. He felt fear, terror, and goosebumps, and wanted to turn back.

sn10.8:1.12.pli: Atha kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
sn10.8:1.12.eng: Then the invisible spirit Sivaka called out:
sn10.8:1.12.comm: Sivaka appears alongside Mucalinda at DN 32:10.12. Mucalinda supported the Buddha after his awakening, as Sivaka supports Anāthapiṇḍika here. Sivaka might be identified with Shiva (see SN 2.21).

sn10.8:2.1.comm: The commentary says that the “hundred” in the first two lines should be multiplied by the “thousand” of line three, but the Chinese parallels at SA 592 and SA2 186 prefer the more modest figure.

sn10.8:2.5.eng: these are not worth a sixteenth part

sn10.8:3.3.eng: Going forward is better for you,

sn10.8:4.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
sn10.8:4.1.eng: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

sn10.8:4.2.pli: Dutiyampi kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
sn10.8:4.2.eng: But for a second time, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. …

sn10.8:4.3.pli: Dutiyampi kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
sn10.8:4.3.eng: For a second time the invisible spirit Sivaka called out …

sn10.8:6.3.eng: “… Going forward is better for you,

sn10.8:7.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
sn10.8:7.1.eng: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

sn10.8:7.2.pli: Tatiyampi kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
sn10.8:7.2.eng: But for a third time, light vanished and darkness appeared to him. …

sn10.8:7.3.pli: Tatiyampi kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi:
sn10.8:7.3.eng: For a third time the invisible spirit Sivaka called out …

sn10.8:9.3.eng: “… Going forward is better for you,

sn10.8:10.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.
sn10.8:10.1.eng: Then darkness vanished and light appeared to Anāthapiṇḍika. His fear, terror, and goosebumps settled down.

sn10.8:10.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sītavanaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
sn10.8:10.2.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went to the Cool Grove and approached the Buddha.

sn10.8:11.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya abbhokāse caṅkamati.
sn10.8:11.1.eng: Now at that time the Buddha had risen at the crack of dawn and was walking mindfully in the open.

sn10.8:11.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn10.8:11.2.eng: He saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance.

sn10.8:11.3.pli: Disvāna caṅkamā orohitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn10.8:11.3.eng: So he stepped down from the walking path, sat down on the seat spread out,

sn10.8:11.4.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:

sn10.8:11.6.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati, nāmena maṃ bhagavā ālapatīti, haṭṭho udaggo tattheva bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.8:11.6.eng: Then Anāthapiṇḍika thought, “The Buddha calls me by name!” Smiling and elated, he bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said to him,

sn10.8:11.7.eng: “Sir, I trust the Buddha slept well?”
sn10.8:11.7.comm: After all that drama, he asks a simple question, as one does when nervous. But the Buddha’s reply is more than satisfying.

sn10.8:12.1.comm: These verses are also at AN 3.35:8.1.

sn10.8:13.1.eng: Since they’ve cut off all clinging,

sn10.8:13.2.eng: and removed the stress from the heart,

sn10.9:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn10.9:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn10.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sukkā bhikkhunī mahatiyā parisāya parivutā dhammaṃ deseti.
sn10.9:1.2.eng: Now, at that time the nun Sukkā was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

sn10.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho sukkāya bhikkhuniyā abhippasanno yakkho rājagahe rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn10.9:1.3.eng: Then a native spirit was so devoted to Sukkā that he went from street to street and from square to square, and on that occasion recited these verses:

sn10.9:2.1.eng: “What’s up with these people in Rājagaha?

sn10.9:2.2.eng: They sleep like they’ve been drinking mead!

sn10.9:2.4.eng: as she’s teaching the state free of death.
sn10.9:2.4.comm: I have translated the slightly varying texts here and at Thig 3.6 the same, except this line which is clearly different.

sn10.9:3.2.eng: it’s as if they drink it up,

sn10.9:3.4.eng: like travelers enjoying a cool cloud.”

sn11.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn11.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn11.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn11.1:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, the titans marched against the gods.
sn11.1:2.1.comm: The gods (deva) stem from Proto Indo-European dyew, “shining, sky, heavens” (cf. Pali diva, “day”; English “day”, however, is a false friend), while the titans (asura) are the negative form of Proto Indo-European sóh₂wl̥, “sun”, so asura is “sunless, night”. As the day vanquishes the dark of night each dawn, the gods defeat the titans. Victory is sweet but short-lived, for soon follows dusk, at which the titans prevail and plunge the world into darkness once more (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.5.1, Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa 3.2.9.7). Note: The Vedas know the sense of asura as (human) “lord”; but given that the opposition between deva and asura is known to the Avesta, I assume that is the older sense and the sense “lord” derivative; cf. English “titan of industry”.

sn11.1:2.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo suvīraṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.1:2.2.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the godling Suvīra,

sn11.1:2.3.eng: ‘Dear Suvīra, the titans march against the gods!

sn11.1:2.4.eng: Go, and march against the titans!’

sn11.1:2.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, suvīro devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā pamādaṃ āpādesi.
sn11.1:2.5.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But he fell into negligence.
sn11.1:2.5.comm: Sakka himself is accused of negligence by Moggallāna at MN 37:11.2. Sakka or Indra is a heroic deity associated with the accomplishment of great deeds, and accordingly here he extols energy. | As a historical curio, in the earliest mention of Sanskrit pramāda (Rig Veda 8.2.18), it is the “exhilaration” from drinking Soma which grants the gods led by Indra unsleeping tirelessness. This passage lends support to the idea that Soma was originally a stimulant, perhaps ephedra. Nonetheless, pamāda became associated with drunkenness and hence “negligence”.

sn11.1:2.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo suvīraṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.1:2.6.eng: For a second time Sakka addressed Suvīra,

sn11.1:2.7.eng: ‘Dear Suvīra, the titans march against the gods!

sn11.1:2.8.eng: Go, and march against the titans!’

sn11.1:2.9.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, suvīro devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā dutiyampi pamādaṃ āpādesi.
sn11.1:2.9.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But for a second time he fell into negligence.

sn11.1:2.10.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo suvīraṃ devaputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn11.1:2.10.eng: For a third time Sakka addressed Suvīra,

sn11.1:2.11.eng: ‘Dear Suvīra, the titans march against the gods!

sn11.1:2.12.eng: Go, and march against the titans!’

sn11.1:2.13.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, suvīro devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā tatiyampi pamādaṃ āpādesi.
sn11.1:2.13.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Suvīra. But for a third time he fell into negligence.

sn11.1:2.14.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo suvīraṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.1:2.14.eng: Then Sakka addressed the godling Suvīra in verse:

sn11.1:3.3.eng: without working for it or trying hard—

sn11.1:4.1.eng: ‘That a lazy man who does no work,

sn11.1:4.4.comm: Disa is imperative of disati (“show”) in the sense “render, bestow, confer”.

sn11.1:5.2.eng: where a lazy man who does no work

sn11.1:6.2.eng: that we might find the happiness

sn11.1:7.2.eng: where one can live happily without working,
sn11.1:7.2.comm: The Chinese texts at both SA2 43 (活) and SA 1114 (生) appears to support jīvati rather than jīyati. Bingenheimer at SA2 43 has, “Have you ever seen or heard of someone who, without effort, attains happiness in life?” Both Chinese texts have more lines than the Pali; given that the Pali has five lines, it seems likely the text has suffered loss. I translate according to what I guess the meaning to have been.

sn11.1:7.3.eng: that surely would be extinguishment’s path!

sn11.1:8.1.pli: So hi nāma, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sakaṃ puññaphalaṃ upajīvamāno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kārento uṭṭhānavīriyassa vaṇṇavādī bhavissati.
sn11.1:8.1.eng: Since, mendicants, even that Sakka, lord of gods—while living off of the fruit of his good deeds, and ruling as sovereign lord over these gods of the thirty-three—will speak in praise of initiative and energy,

sn11.1:8.2.pli: Idha kho taṃ, bhikkhave, sobhetha, yaṃ tumhe evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā uṭṭhaheyyātha ghaṭeyyātha vāyameyyātha appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya, asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
sn11.1:8.2.eng: you can excel here, for you who have gone forth in such a well explained teaching and training can try hard, strive, and make an effort to attain the unattained, achieve the unachieved, and realize the unrealized.”
sn11.1:8.2.comm: This is a tricky construction. The idiom idha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, sobhetha occurs several times, always in the same context: someone is said to have some quality, and the mendicants are encouraged to have it even more so. The preceding clause usually includes hi nāma, suggesting a dependent clause (SN 11.2:8.2, SN 11.4:13.2, SN 35.103:5.7, Kd 16:6.4.2, Kd 5:4.3.1). Sobhetha is second plural optative in the sense “you all can (out)shine or excel”.
